message: Is there Anyone here who uses NodeJS in real projects ?

data.message:
You mean here in this group? I think a few do. As in: yes.
So, where does this take the conversaion?

Just wanted to ask about the reasons that would make you choose using it. Some real and personal reasons, I already did a lot of searches, but not convinced yet with what I got of results, So I'm seeking for personal thoughts.

And the second question is how did you managed to start thinking of it as a server side language ? How did you start to think of it differently ?
Mohamed Alaa El Din تطلع الطلعة دي؟

I've used Node.js in a realtime project. That depended heavily on sockets and instant responses. During the lifetime of the project only 3 or 4 requests cycles are made and around 10 sockets events are fired. 

I used Node.js as a rest server with AngularJS. Node is quite responsive when it comes to heavy number of requests. 

It's also all about asynchronous calls, So you'll face a lot of hard times trying to figure out why a function returns undefined when it should've returned a value. Then you'll figure out its event-driven approach, And you'll really have to get your head around it in order to be able to create anything using Node.js. I literally mean it, If you can't work with events and manage your code according to it, just stay away from Node.js, But If you did, you'll find programming using Node.js just magical :)

Mohamed Meligy i have used it in a project  before i was trying to do real time notification but i found that the server is down after five notification ,so i stop the service what is the specification of the host if i want to use it again?
The backend of https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/boximize-structured-note-taking/id828889086?mt=8 is built using Node.js and dynamoDB (not released yet though) .. as Rafael Adel said it's magical :)
I think Randa Hisham may have meant to mention Rafael Adel in her comment mentioning me. Raph?

yes ,
for ( real time notifications using socket.io ) in a project
and for a file monitoring script ( in house project )

We use it in our backend at elmenus.com, it's API centric with our website and mobile apps connecting to it. It's not for every kind of application so don't follow the hype and use it for the wrong reasons just because it's cool and new (although sometimes this is good enough reason). For us, it's been covering all our needs, attracted the right kind of developers for us and is supporting our real time needs for apps like our push server and a socket.io based application we're developing
Don't go for something real without async.js though

I didn't use it in production, but I've been learning about real-time web apps for some time now.

Some people do the non real-time part of their website with the technology familiar to them & do the real-time part only with NodeJS. 

This is an example using django & NodeJS, but it can be applied with any technology http://www.maxburstein.com/blog/realtime-django-using-nodejs-and-socketio/

Also, most technologies now allow you to do real-time apps. With .net there is SignalR. With Java there is Jetty. You'll find also for Python, Ruby, etc

Mohamed Meligy Sorry for late response. About your question Randa Hisham.

To be honest, I was hosting the app on a personal computer and was a part of a network.

But generally, Node.js creates it's own process (web server) and listens on a particular port. You won't need Apache at all. In fact if you want to host a Node.js application on apache you'll have to do some work. 

So you can host a Node.js app nearly on any server but it varies in the difficulty to get it running. 

1 -  You can just run Node.js by itself on a server without apache and tell it to listen on a certain port.. But you'll have to manage error handling and stuff like that. Becaus if an exception is thrown and not handled the process of the application stops and will not be responding until you restart that process. 

You'll have to make sure also that no other application on your server is using the same port node is using. especially if you're using web sockets.

2 - You can use Node.js in combination with nginx to create proxies i think in order to prevent any port blocking (not really sure if this is the only benefit )

3 - You can host it on Apache, But you'll have to do some Virtual Hosts stuff. Not really sure.

4 - You can use PaaS or IaaS, Which handles nearly every server maintenance task. Like rebooting in case of an exception, load balancing, deployment and starting/stopping your app.

PaaS is like Heroku and Nodejitsu 
IaaS is like Amazone AWS

Note: I did some researches before and readings to get this information. Please if there's something incorrect about it tell me. Thanks.

Thanks Mohamed Meligy I will take it from here :D (My Favorite Part Thank You)

Node.js is built upon libuv, a cross-platform library that abstracts apis/syscalls for asynchronous (non-blocking) input/output provided by the supported OSes (Unix, OS X and Windows at least).
